name: Setting the record straight
description: For too long, the history of Australia was only told in mainstream films through a white lens. First Nations people have used the camera as a means of truth-telling and setting the record straight for decades.

key_work.title: Bill Onus
key_work.brief_description: To Bill Onus, sharing his culture was an act of resistance and reclamation of power. The Yorta Yorta activist, artist and entrepreneur had roles in several Australian films, documented Aboriginal life through home movies and is likely one of the first Aboriginal filmmakers.

links.description: The Sapphires uses a true story as inspiration. In a time where Australian government policy enforced Aboriginal children being taken away from their families, the Cummeragunja Songbirds, also known as The Sapphires, travelled to Vietnam to sing for the troops during the war.

links.description: Larissa Behrendt is a Eualeyai/Kamillaroi lawyer and filmmaker whose films expose the holes in Australia’s legal system. Innocence Betrayed follows a 23-year long fight for justice of the families of three murdered Aboriginal children, the killer of whom has never been convicted.

end.title: Beneath Clouds
end.creator_credit: Ivan Sen, Teresa-Jayne Hanlon, AFFC, Australian Film Commission, Autumn Films, New South Wales Film and Television Office and SBS Independent
end.brief_description: Ivan Sen’s debut feature continues the story of one of his acclaimed short films, ‘Tears’. Two disaffected teenagers, Vaughn and Lena (played by non-professional actors Damian Pitt and Dannielle Hall), meet on the road as they flee their troubled backgrounds and head to the city.

constellations_other.name: Setting the record straight

links.description: Beneath Clouds follows two young people as they hitchhike through regional NSW. Vaughan has just escaped juvenile prison, and Lena is running from home. The two grapple with issues faced by many young First Nations people; identity, belonging and navigating colonial systems.
